ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I refined some of my preexisting quantitative analysis skills and expanded my horizons with new techniques that I hadn't used before or had used without a concrete understanding of how to interpret them clearly. A useful course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Treiman was nice enough, but the class was essentially just reading off lecture slides, which is fine but not terribly engaging as a teaching technique. Technically a lecture class, but the enrollment size made it have aspects of a seminar. Definitely practical and useful as a class, but not the most exciting way to spend an afternoon.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in quantitative social science and don't want to dive into courses offered by the statistics department, this is probably a good bet. Not the most engaging course I've ever taken, but practical, and the problem sets (especially the later ones) guide you through the techniques which you will eventually use for your final paper, and you're given a good deal of independence in your data set choice and research question.
